stories.title: Child Agricultural Labor
prompts: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing.
Nunc eu sapien a augue iaculis consequat?
Duis cursus erat tortor, quis semper enim rhoncus.
Nullam cursus diam eu vulputate finibus?

regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center, Joe McTyre Photograph Collection

regions.text: How young is too young? The exploitation of child labor is a dark part of American history. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1936 ended child labor in harsh factory and mine conditions. But many children continue to labor on American farms. In Georgia, at 16 years of age, children can work on farms. With consent from parents, children as young as 12 can work during non-school hours. Many children assist their parents with chores on the family farm, but on numerous commercial farms children still work in harsh conditions with little regulation and protection.

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Georgia Archives, Vanishing Georgia Photographic Collection, tho098
regions.caption: Workers Picking Cotton, Thomas County, ca. 1895

regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center, Vincent M. Irick Photographs
regions.caption: Boys with Oxen on Judge Spencer's Farm

regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center, Vincent M. Irick Photographs
regions.caption: Boy carrying Collards on Judge Spencer's Farm

regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center, Vincent M. Irick Photographs
regions.caption: Boy carrying a Bucket on Judge Spencer's Farm

regions.text: Children were once a source of labor on many Southern farms. Often children were taken out of school to help on the farms. These boys worked on a farm near Faceville, Georgia in 1899.

regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center, Vincent M. Irick Photographs
regions.caption: African-Americans working Strawberry Patch, Fort Valley, Peach County, Georgia

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Georgia Archives, Vanishing Georgia Photographic Collection, brw159
regions.caption: Members of an African-American family picking cotton in 1940.

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, National Child Labor Committee Collection
regions.caption: Ten-year old Rader Copeland plows a field in Valdosta, Georgia, in 1915. "He was plowing during school hours and will lose 10 weeks of schooling," the photographer wrote. "His father said that he needed the boy's help. He plows, plants, chops cotton, picks cotton. The father said: 'He ain't very fast.'"

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, National Child Labor Committee Collection
regions.caption: Children thrashing corn during school hours on a farm near Dublin, Georgia, in 1915. According to the photographer, "Many such light occupations fall to the lot of the Georgia child."

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy WSB Radio Records, Special Collections and Archives, Georgia State University, Atlanta
regions.caption: Child picking cotton at Tucker, Georgia

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy U. Roberto Romano Papers, Archives & Special Collection at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries

regions.text: "The first day I was burned. I was in short sleeves and shorts. I thought, Thank God I got through it."
Pedro E. (age 15)
Describing working without protective gear, 2009

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy U. Roberto Romano Papers, Archives & Special Collection at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries
regions.caption: Yesenia, 12-years-old, leaves school early to pick onions.

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy U. Roberto Romano Papers, Archives & Special Collection at the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, University of Connecticut Libraries
regions.caption: An estimated 400,000 to 500,000 children work in the agricultural industry in the United States, many of whom are US citizens. Texas accounts for 60% of the onion seed stock and 25% of the onions consumed in this country.

regions.text: Under the Fair Labor Standards Act, workers as young as 14 can work in non-hazardous agriculture jobs outside of school hours. Younger children are frequently hired illegally, however, and many toil in dangerous conditions. Human Rights Watch estimates that as many as 500,000 children work on commercial farms in the U.S.

stories.title: Voting Rights
prompts: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing.
Nunc eu sapien a augue iaculis consequat?
Duis cursus erat tortor, quis semper enim rhoncus.
Nullam cursus diam eu vulputate finibus?

regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center

regions.text: The right to vote is considered a fundamental entitlement of citizens in the United States. Participation in our democratic process requires the vote. However, most Americans have had to struggle to gain, and maintain, this significant right. Until ratification of the 14th Amendment (1868), most voters were land-owning white males.

slides.title: We the People without the Vote

regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center

regions.text: On January 29, 1848, 215 male voters elected Moses Formwalt mayor in Atlanta's first municipal election. The polling place was Thomas Kile's grocery, located at today's Five Points in downtown Atlanta.

slides.title: Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division
regions.caption: Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton

regions.text: The same year Atlanta held its first municipal election, the Seneca Falls Convention launched the American woman's suffrage movement. The convention's Declaration of Sentiments declared, "all men and women are created equal."

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division
regions.caption: Hand colored photograph of a woman (Columbia) holding a document and standing between two kneeling slaves. The slave to her left, a man, holds a U.S. flag; the slave to her right, a woman, is draped in the U.S. flag.

regions.text: As women pushed for the right to vote, African Americans did the same. For four million enslaved blacks, the American Civil War was fought for freedom and citizenship. Union victory emboldened African American efforts to gain voting rights.

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division
regions.caption: One of several large commemorative prints marking the enactment, on March 30, 1870, of the Fifteenth Amendment and showing the grand May 19 celebratory parade in Baltimore. Here the central image shows the parade crossing a green in sight of Baltimore's Washington Monument.

regions.text: Congress approved the 15th Amendment during Reconstruction. As ratified in 1870, it stated that the "right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of race, color, or previous condition of servitude." Decades of racist policies challenged the clear intent of the amendment.

In the 1890s, Georgia's woman's suffrage movement sprang to life when Helen Augusta Howard founded the Georgia Woman Suffrage Association. In 1895, the newly formed Equal Suffrage League hosted the National American Woman Suffrage Association annual conference in Atlanta. This was the first time the conference met outside Washington, D.C. Many famous suffragists attended including Susan B. Anthony and Anna Howard Shaw.

slides.title: "Chinese Father Proud of Three Happy Children"

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Atlanta Journal-Constitution
regions.caption: Chinese Father Proud of Three Happy Children

regions.text: Asian Americans were denied citizenship as well as the right to vote. In 1898 the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that children born on American soil were citizens. Nevertheless, Chinese living in the U.S., such as Lum Ling of Atlanta, faced onging discrimination.

regions.caption: Dr. W.E.B. Du Bois

regions.text: W.E.B. Du Bois was a prominent figure in Atlanta and a faculty member at Atlanta University. He played a critical role in founding both the Niagara Movement and, in 1909, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The NAACP remains an influential advocate for African American civil and voting rights. "In detail our demands are clear and unequivocal," Du Bois wrote. "First, we would vote; with the right to vote goes everything: Freedom, manhood, the honor of your wives, the chastity of your daughters, the right to work, and the chance to rise, and let no man listen to those who deny this. ... We want full manhood suffrage, and we want it now, henceforth and forever."

regions.caption: Lugenia Burns Hope, wife of John Hope, the president of Atlanta University, was a leading association member, social activist, and community organizer.

regions.text: The woman's suffrage movement in the South largely excluded African American women. To fill the void, black women formed the National Association of Colored Women (1896) to advocate for their rights as women and blacks simultaneously. Lugenia Burns Hope, wife of John Hope, the president of Atlanta University, was a leading association member, social activist, and community organizer.

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division
regions.caption: A figure representing "Votes for Women" marches across America, symbolizing the awakening desire for women's suffrage.

regions.text: The 19th amendment guaranteed all American women the right to vote. Although Georgia voters rejected the amendment in 1919, it was ratified by the required number of states and then by Congress in 1920. Georgia didn't ratify the amendment until 1970.

regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center
regions.caption: Rebecca Latimer Felton was the first female U.S. senator. A staunch advocate for women's rights, she was an equally vocal and determined white supremacist.

regions.text: When Governor Thomas Hardwick appointed Rebecca Latimer Felton of Atlanta to fill the vacancy left by the death of Senator Thomas E. Watson, Felton became the first female U.S. senator. Sworn in on November 21, 1922, her term of office ended on November 22. A staunch advocate for women's rights, she was an equally vocal and determined white supremacist.  She said, "When the women of the country come in and sit with you, though there may be but a very few in the next few years, I pledge you that you will get ability, you will get integrity of purpose, you will get exalted patriotism, and you will get unstinted usefulness."  Rebecca Latimer Felton's speech before the Senate gave a prediction on the women that would follow her. To date, no woman has been elected from Georgia to the U.S. Senate.

regions.acknowledgement: Courtesy Georgia State University, Atlanta
regions.caption: Voters cast ballots in the race for Fifth District U.S. Congress in 1946.

regions.text: All-white primaries, literary tests, and poll taxes disenfranchised African Americans in Georgia and across the South. In 1944, pivotal court decision ruled the pro-segregationist Democratic Party's whites-only primary system unconstitutional. That opened the door for African American voters throughout the Democratic South.

regions.acknowledgement: Gift of June Dobbs Butts
regions.caption: John Wesley Dobbs, known unofficially as the "Mayor of Auburn Avenue," believed African American suffrage held the key to political and economic progress.He co-founded the Atlanta Negro Voters League in 1946.

regions.text: John Wesley Dobbs, known unofficially as the "Mayor of Auburn Avenue," believed African American suffrage held the key to political and economic progress. In 1946, Dobbs and attorney A.T. Walden cofounded the Atlanta Negro Voters League. The nonpartisan league recommended candidates it felt would serve black Atlanta communities.

slides.title: Signing of the Voting Rights Act

regions.text: The Voting Rights Act of 1965 guaranteed African Americans their rights under the 15th Amendment almost a century after ratification in 1870. The act forbade discrimination on the basis of race and included provisions for enforcement.

regions.caption: Anti-draft demonstration at the Fulton County Selective Service Board offices

regions.text: The Voting Rights Act did not settle all issues related to voting. As the war in Vietnam dragged on, student activists argued that if 18-year-old males could be drafted for military service, they should be able to vote. The 26th Amendment (1971) lowered the voting age to 18.

regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center
regions.caption: A staff person of the Southern Regional Council's Voter Education Project encouraging voter participation in downtown Atlanta in 1973.

regions.text: The Voter Education Project, founded in 1962 in Atlanta, sponsored education programs on voter rights and conducted voter registration drives throughout the South. Although it closed in 1992, similar organizations continue to encourage voter participation.
In 1975, Congress amended the Voting Rights Act to provide language assistance at election polls, a policy that remains controversial.

slides.title: Challenges to the Voting Rights Act

regions.text: In Shelby County v. Holder (2013), the U.S. Supreme Court declared Section 4(b) of the Voting Rights Act unconstitutional. The decision questioned the continued validity of federal government oversight of state and local elections. Many believed the oversight, intended to prevent restrictive practices, was no longer needed. Others feared that the court decision opened the door to new efforts to deny people of color their voting rights.  Do you think that American citizens still require protections that ensure their right to vote?

regions.text: Maynard Jackson was the first African American mayor of Atlanta. He served two terms (1974-1982) and a third from 1990 to 1994. He also worked, along with Andrew Young, to bring the Olympic Games to Atlanta.
Which mayor founded the Atlanta-based Coca-Cola Company and led the city during World War I?

regions.caption: James Key
regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center

regions.caption: Asa Candler
regions.acknowledgement: Emory University, Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library

regions.caption: James Woodard
regions.acknowledgement: Emory University, Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library

regions.caption: Ivan Allen Jr.
regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center
Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center, Atlanta History Photograph Collection

regions.text: Ever the entrepreneur, Asa Candler began his career as a successful manufacturer of patent medicines. In 1888, he purchased the rights to a tonic medicine called Coca-Cola. Candler rebranded the tonic as a soft drink and founded The Coca-Cola Company. Voters elected Candler mayor in 1916 on his success as a businessman.
Which mayor served as co-chair for the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games and pushed the city towards international status?

regions.caption: Andrew Young
regions.acknowledgement: Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center

regions.caption: William B. Hartsfield

Courtesy Atlanta Journal-Constitution Photographic Archive, Special Collections and Archives, Georgia State University, Atlanta

regions.text: Diplomat, politician, pastor, and civil rights activist, Andrew Young served Georgia and the United States in many roles. He was the executive director of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, a U.S. congressman (1973 to 1976), and ambassador to the United Nations during the administration of President Jimmy Carter. As mayor of Atlanta in the 1980s, he helped secure the bid for the 1996 Olympic Games.
Which Atlanta mayor served in city government during both the Maynard Jackson and Andrew Young administrations?

regions.caption: Shirley Franklin

regions.text: Shirley Franklin, Atlanta's 58th mayor, was the first female African American mayor of a major Southern city. Voters elected her to two terms (2002-2010). Previously, she served on the Commission of Cultural Affairs in Mayor Maynard Jackson's administration and was appointed chief administrative officer and city manager while Andrew Young was mayor.
Which mayor presented the Beatles with the key to the city?

Kenan Research Center at the Atlanta History Center, Allen Family Photographs

regions.text: Ivan Allen Jr. was mayor from 1962 to 1970. He steered Atlanta through pivotal economic and physical changes to the urban landscape and maintained civic peace during the Civil Rights Movement.
